Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Head and Neck

diagnoses.name: Chronic sinusitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the sinuses that persists long-term, potentially contributing to dysosmia and obstructive sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive sleep apnea syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by repetitive pauses in breathing during sleep due to throat muscles intermittently relaxing and blocking the airway.

diagnoses.name: Neurofibromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder causing tumors to form on nerve tissue, which can lead to arteriovenous malformations and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Malignant otitis externa
diagnoses.description: A severe infection of the outer ear and bone, often seen in immunocompromised individuals, leading to severe pain and potentially lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus/Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome can lead to various neurologic complications and infections, presenting as arteriovenous malformations, lymphadenopathy, and otitis externa.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, commonly the lungs and lymph glands, causing lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in the lymphatic system, leading to lymphadenopathy among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing inflammation of the blood vessels, which can lead to symptoms including sinusitis and otitis externa.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation, present as arteriovenous malformations.

diagnoses.name: Acute otitis externa
diagnoses.description: An infection of the outer ear canal, often referred to as 'swimmer's ear,' leading to pain and potential lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often features symptoms such as dry eyes and dry mouth, which could also lead to complications that affect other parts of the body, potentially influencing blood sugar levels and causing hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: While typically associated with hyperglycemia, management of diabetes with insulin can sometimes lead to hypoglycemia. Secondary complications could potentially lead to conditions that mimic or cause symptoms like bronchitis due to immune system compromise.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs in the body, commonly the lungs and lymph nodes, leading to Lymphadenopathy and presenting symptoms similar to bronchitis.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT)
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to the development of abnormal blood vessels, might cause arteriovenous malformations. This condition could theoretically influence systemic symptoms and potentially impact other elements of health.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder characterized by inflammation of the blood vessels, which can affect various organs, including the eyes (potentially leading to dry eyes), lungs (causing symptoms similar to bronchitis), and potentially influence vascular structures leading to arteriovenous malformations.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that can cause dry eyes (part of secondary Sjögren's syndrome) and can have systemic effects including Lymphadenopathy. Arteriovenous malformations are less commonly associated but can occur as part of the disease's vascular manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, which could theoretically account for various symptoms including eye complications (such as dry eyes) and potentially impact blood sugar control or vascular structures (arteriovenous malformations).

diagnoses.name: Lupus (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the eyes (dry eyes), possibly influence blood sugar levels (hypoglycemia), lead to lymph node enlargement (Lymphadenopathy), and lung involvement mimicking bronchitis.

diagnoses.name: Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis
diagnoses.description: A rare cancer that can produce nodules or masses in various parts of the body, including the lymph nodes (Lymphadenopathy) and lungs (symptoms resembling bronchitis), and affect other organs potentially impacting eye health.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it typically manifests with symptoms such as Lymphadenopathy, and could theoretically lead to dry eyes as part of its symptom complex. While its direct link to arteriovenous malformations and hypoglycemia is less clear, systemic effects of the infection might loosely correspond with some aspects of the symptom set.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.rationale: Weight gain and hearing loss can be symptoms of hypothyroidism. Although thrombocytopenia, thromboembolic disease, and basophilia are less common, thyroid dysfunction can affect various systems in the body, potentially influencing coagulation and blood cell counts.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.rationale: This condition can lead to increased red blood cell mass, which might explain basophilia. It can also increase the risk of thromboembolic diseases due to the increased viscosity of the blood. Weight gain is not directly associated, but fatigue and lethargy can lead to decreased activity.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)
diagnoses.rationale: CML often presents with an increased number of granulocytes (basophils are a type), which might explain basophilia. It can also lead to an increased risk of bleeding (thrombocytopenia) and thrombosis. Weight gain and hearing loss are not typical symptoms but can be associated with complications or treatments.

diagnoses.name: Essential Thrombocythemia
diagnoses.rationale: This disorder can increase the platelet count leading to thromboembolic complications. Some patients might experience thrombocytopenia as a result of treatment. Weight gain is not a direct symptom, but fatigue and related symptoms can indirectly lead to weight gain.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder increases the risk of thromboembolic diseases. It doesn't directly cause weight gain, hearing loss, or basophilia, but the systemic nature of the disorder could indirectly relate to such symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Myelodysplastic Syndromes
diagnoses.rationale: This group of disorders can affect the blood and bone marrow, potentially leading to thrombocytopenia and basophilia. Thromboembolic events can occur due to alterations in blood components. Direct links to weight gain and hearing loss are not common but can be related to the overall health decline.

diagnoses.name: Myelofibrosis
diagnoses.rationale: Similar to other myeloproliferative disorders, it can result in anemia, thrombocytopenia, and an increased risk of thrombosis. Basophilia is also a characteristic feature. Weight gain and hearing loss are not typical symptoms but can occur in the context of disease progression and treatment side effects.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by snoring and sleep disruption, it can lead to weight gain. While it is less commonly associated with the other symptoms listed, systemic inflammation resulting from untreated sleep apnea might indirectly contribute to a prothrombotic state.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This condition can lead to weight gain, especially central obesity. While it is typically not associated with hearing loss, thrombocytopenia, or basophilia directly, it can predispose individuals to thromboembolic events due to hypercoagulability.

diagnoses.name: Metabolic Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily associated with obesity, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and insulin resistance, components of the metabolic syndrome may indirectly increase the risk of thromboembolic diseases. Direct connections to hearing loss, thrombocytopenia, or basophilia are less clear, but metabolic syndrome's impact on overall health can potentially exacerbate or correlate with these conditions.

diagnoses: Allergic Reactions or Anaphylaxis (for Hypersensitivity reactions)
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (could explain lymphadenopathy, hypersensitivity)
Hodgkin's Lymphoma (especially with lymphadenopathy and immune responses)
Adrenal Hyperplasia or related conditions (if considering striae and other systemic symptoms)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) - including Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis
Asthma (in cases where dyspnea is more prominent)
Bladder dysfunction related to neurological disorders

diagnoses.description: A headache of varying intensity, often accompanied by nausea and sensitivity to light and sound.
A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, ringing in the ear (tinnitus), and hearing loss.
A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves.
An infection of the vestibular nerve, leading to vertigo, nausea, and some hearing loss.
A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain.
A benign tumor on the main nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain.
Often called a ministroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke.
A tick-borne illness causing rash, facial paralysis, and arthritis.
A condition in which the force of the blood against the artery walls is too high, potentially causing headaches and other symptoms.
Headaches due to overuse of medication to treat headache symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by severe head pain followed or accompanied by sensory disturbances such as flashes of light, blind spots, tingling in the arms and legs, nausea, vomiting, and increased sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. These can include weakness, vertigo, headache, visual disturbances (such as scintillation), and difficulty speaking (aphasia).

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms may include weakness on one side of the body, difficulty speaking, vertigo, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). MS blocks the messages between your brain and your body, leading to symptoms like fatigue, weakness, vertigo, and difficulty in speech.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Any growth of abnormal cells within the brain. Depending on the location and size of the tumor, symptoms could include headache, weakness, difficulty with speech, and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Specific types of epilepsy may present with visual disturbances and speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Neuritis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the vestibular nerve, which can cause vertigo and dizziness.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In some cases, patients might experience a migraine-like headache and symptoms affecting their visual and speech functions.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain as a result of infection. Symptoms can include headache, weakness, seizures, vertigo, visual disturbances, and speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from restricted blood flow to the back of the brain. Symptoms can include vertigo, dizziness, headache, difficulty speaking, and other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: Migraine headaches can cause severe throbbing pain or a pulsing sensation, usually on one side of the head. It's often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and extreme sensitivity to light and sound. Migraine attacks can cause significant pain for hours to days and can be so severe that the pain is disabling. Symptoms such as tinnitus and weakness can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's disease
diagnoses.details: Meniere's disease is a disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In most cases, Meniere's disease affects only one ear. It can cause symptoms such as tinnitus, a feeling of fullness in the ear, hearing loss, and balance issues.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.details: Anemia is a condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues. Feeling tired and weak is one of the most common symptoms of anemia. Some individuals with anemia may also experience headaches and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: A brain tumor can manifest with varying symptoms depending on the part of the brain it affects. Common symptoms include headaches (often worse in the morning and gradually decrease after vomiting), weakness on one side of the body, seizures, and sometimes tinnitus or other hearing impairments.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.details: High blood pressure (hypertension) can occasionally cause symptoms when it reaches a high level. These symptoms may include headaches, shortness of breath, and in some cases, tinnitus. Chronic hypertension can lead to more severe health issues including heart disease, stroke, and can cause damage to the kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.details: Chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) is a complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that cannot be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest. Other symptoms can include headache, weakness, and sometimes tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). MS causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Symptoms include fatigue, walking difficulties, weakness, and in some cases, tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes
diagnoses.details: Diabetes, a chronic condition that affects how the body processes blood sugar (glucose), can lead to a variety of symptoms including excessive thirst, urination, hunger, fatigue, blurred vision, and for some, headache and weakness. Diabetes complications can also lead to hearing problems such as tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Lyme disease
diagnoses.details: Lyme disease is caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi and is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected black-legged ticks. Early symptoms may include fever, chills, headache, fatigue, muscle and joint aches, and swollen lymph nodes. In some cases, tinnitus can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency
diagnoses.details: Iron deficiency, the most common nutritional deficiency, can cause anemia and lead to symptoms like fatigue, weakness, and headaches. Some individuals may also experience tinnitus as a symptom of iron deficiency anemia.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Chronic Kidney Disease (secondary to SLE or other systemic diseases)
Hepatitis B or C (associated with cryoglobulinemia or vasculitis)
HIV/AIDS (associated with various hematologic and renal manifestations)
Lymphoma (Hodgkin's or non-Hodgkin's, given the multi-system involvement)
Hepatitis B and C Related Cryoglobulinemia
Hepatitis B and C associated cryoglobulinemia
